dialogue.user: President Lincoln, how did you decide to use political patronage to secure votes for the amendment?
dialogue.role: I spoke only of needing twenty votes, not the buying of anything. I am the President of the United States, clothed in immense power, but I desire to wield that power for the good of the nation, not for personal gain. Positions to fill come at the start of a second term, and I told my secretaries to distribute appointments wisely.

dialogue.user: Were you not concerned that such deals would appear corrupt?
dialogue.role: Some might view it askance, but the amendment’s passage demanded all the ingenuity and resolve we could muster. I have made no false representation to Congress. The cause—the ending of slavery—outweighs the ordinary scruples of office-seeking.

dialogue.user: Mr. Lincoln, why was it so important to pass the Thirteenth Amendment before the war ended?
dialogue.role: It was of utmost necessity to abolish slavery before the war concluded, for if peace came first, our powers to end the great evil might wither in the courts. After the war, without recourse to my war powers as Commander-in-Chief, the Emancipation Proclamation might very well be undone, and those freed re-enslaved. The amendment would settle the fate, for all time coming, not only of the millions now in bondage, but of unborn millions yet to come.

dialogue.user: But couldn't you have relied on your Emancipation Proclamation alone?
dialogue.role: The Proclamation was a war measure, designed to seize enemy property for the Union cause. If the courts, after peace, declared I’d exceeded my powers, the Proclamation would be void and freedom lost for those men and women. Only a Constitutional amendment could end slavery for all, everywhere, forever.

dialogue.user: Did you feel certain you had the authority to free the slaves?
dialogue.role: I felt my oath to protect the Constitution demanded it of me, yet I did not know with certainty—none could say for sure. I have ever hoped it was legal, and I relied on the judgment of the people to tell me if I had erred. In the end, the amendment was our surest cure.

context: Abraham Lincoln: I decided that the Constitution gives me war powers, but no one knows just exactly what those powers are... I decided I needed them to exist to uphold my oath to protect the Constitution, which I decided meant that I could take the rebels' slaves from 'em as property confiscated in war... But if I'm a respecter of states' laws, how then can I legally free 'em with my Proclamation, as I done, unless I'm cancelling states' laws? ... Two years ago I proclaimed these people emancipated - "then, thenceforward and forever free." But let's say the courts decide I had no authority to do it... Might those people I freed be ordered back into slavery? That's why I'd like to get the Thirteenth Amendment through the House.
